Description:
Built in 1974 bungalow. Garage, sitting room, log fire,an aga, 4 bedrooms. The Vicarage is converted into a surgery by Richard Locke and opened in January '98.
Converted back into a Vicarage in September 2003

Was originally Ambridge Court. Bellamy had it coverted into flats. Aldridge re-converted it when he bought the 1500 acres.(15.10.75) 3 farm cottages; the house is principally early eighteenth century. Open air swimming pool

 A field up the Penny Hassett road is 118 acres. Farm in '97 1600 acres:
Long Field is down by Long Wood other field names: 
White Acre
Long meadow
Broad bank
Broadfield
Top field
Oak Bank
High Copse
Lyttleton Covert has pylons in it. Past Ambridge Hall turn left
Lakefield
soils at Home farm and the Estate are quite heavy, with parts that are heavy clay.

Two Farm workers

Market town 5miles from Ambridge..10miles to Felpersham. Clock-tower in the market place where they used to sell cattle.Friday is market day. By pass to ease traffic flow.Take away Balti.Covered market with stall All Saints Church.Canal St.Radio Borsetshire local radio. A Common

15th Century.  There is a country lane opposite, and a mile along it is Brookfield Farm. Function room upstairs. There is a woodburning stove. Car park. Free House. Black and White. Little kitchen upstairs. Door from the restaurant to the bar. Conker trees close. Dogs allowed. 4 bedrooms

1992: Dairy herd 115 Friesians. They rear their own replacements. Sheep flock of 300 mules which are put to a Suffolk tup. They lamb at the end of February 
465 Acres owner occupied farm. Field names; Blacklands, Marney's, Round Robin, Wormitt, the Grove, Trefoil, Midsummer Meadow, The Croft, Skipperley, Lower Parks, Upper Parks, Long Field, Cuckoo Covert, Ashfield, Coombebell, Oakey Bank, Lakey Hill, Lakey Meadow, Burntland, Badger's Bank, Little Field. B&B comments book in Hall. Their cows do not have names only numbers. Old brick and timber house dating back to 16th century. 
Workshop

Silage Clamps 140 acres tenanted at a rent of £50 an acre. Tony also rents 10 acres of accommodation land in the village and a further 22 acres 3-4 miles away. After the herd was sold in 2013 they no longer rent any extra land


Late Victorian red brick farm house, part of the Berrow Estate. 4 beds Kitchen with fitted pine units, Dairy & exshop  pack house.
Backdoor opens into kitchen. Small barn to the left of the farmhouse

There is a big step when you go out of the back door. 
Large farmhouse - family home. Isolated from the road. 
Stable block, with a flat above, out buildings and an indoor riding school. Tack room where the -horse mad girls hang out.  Some of the outbuildings have been converted into the Veterinary Surgery with car park. Not much land with the stables however it is surrounded by Brookfield farm land.
3 and a half miles from Ambridge. There is a firm at Loxley Barrett who make good pens. Loxley Barratt primary school - assumed in 2008 to have 200 - 250 children
The Fletchers live in Glebelands

Building starts October 1991. Ready early 1991. Parish Council taking applications. Jack Woolley put up the land - not the money. EP 10378. 4 Houses : 1 (2 beds) for rent; 1 (2 beds) for sale; 2 (3 beds) for sale; 2 (2 bed) bungalows.

Was built as The Lodge for Arkwright Hall. Close to Grey Gables. There is a stained glass window in the hallway. It is very light. Could have a lovely view of Arkwright Lake. Oak kitchen with glass-fronted cupboards and built in hob. Black and White timbered building. Small front gate. There is an open fire There is a conservatory at The Lodge and a bird table. Study.
2008 summerhouse. There is a hatch from the kitchen through to the breakfast - diningroom.

One of the red brick outbuildings at Brookfield. Renovated /rebuilt in 1954.  It was traditionally the home of the farm worker. Very small, said that there is not enough room to swing a cat in. In 1992 Jill turned it into a holiday cottage. Down stairs there is a sitting room and a small kitchen. Upstairs two bedrooms. There must be a bathroom but we don’t know where. No hallway, the stairs are through a door in the sitting room.
No garden

Has a hedge. -A pair of semi-detached  cottages built in 1960 by Charles Grenville. Opposite Ambridge Hall close to Home and Willow Farms. Were owned by the Estate and now by Jack Woolley. Tom and Pru were the first people to live in Keeper’s Cottage. 
Two Bedrooms (after her illness Pru was unable to manage the stairs). 
Both cottages have a small hall, living room (to one side of the hall), and kitchen at the end of the hall the staircase is visible from the front door. Both have neat, well kept gardens. There is a porch at April Cottage is the mirror of  Keeper’s.
Tom and Pru / Len and Mary Thomas move into the new cottages on 12.5.1960.
 Address: Keeper's Cottage, Felpersham Road, Ambridge. (2004)
Small cottage next door to the Bull. Bathroom upstairs at the back of the house.  In the garden is both a garden shed and a greenhouse

Thatch roof. Pine staircase. Whitewashed walls. Sitting room, dining room, kitchen,  Open fire. Black and white thatched cottage very pretty.Used in a postcard for Ambridge.  When Walter was living in it fall into disrepair, since then it has had : New roof, new staircase (pine), and a new gable end. New thatch in 1977.  Downstairs is a sitting room with large open fire, dining room and kitchen. Upstairs; two bedrooms and bathroom. 
In the, what used to be, a well maintained back garden, there is a large old shed and a disused well.  In spring there is a perfusion of Primroses in both gardens.  Straddle stone (stone mushroom) at front of cottage.
When the Hathaway's moved in in April 1999. They built an extension out the back  - that enlarged the kitchen and gave space for a small office and a downstairs loo. Upstairs the second bedroom became a nursery (repainted after the miscarriage) and improved the bathroom. (And Jason removed the Honeysuckle after which the cottage had been named). Hallway from front door with reception room on either side. You can see the back garden from the road
Has a shop front onto the street. Marks office used to be called Hebden and Gupta. Has now become Usha's Borchester office.
35 acres of the land became part of Brookfield in 1974

central heating -Built in 1840s, very small, next door to church, Phil and Jill Archer moved in in 2001. Very pretty, two bedrooms, living room, kitchen, small hall,  conservatory. In 1986 Mark and Shula renovated - put in central heating etc. They were going to replace the thatching but bats were found in the roof and the process was delayed, (we did not hear on air if they got round to it after the bats had left). Small walled garden with lawn & patio (2012). Letty Lawson-Hope left Glebe Cottage to Doris for her lifetime along with 4 acres of land in 1958.  Later Dan brought the freehold. Dan and Doris spent their retirement there.  It was in Glebe Cottage that Doris died.
They have a cricket team

There is a car park at the market. Monday is market day.Hungarian Restaurant. Car Auctions. Grand restaurant; La Strada. Health Food shop "Benson's". Offices of Jefferson Crabtree. Job Centre. Main Post 17 miles from Ambridge. Paper The Felpersham Post.Football ground. Ayleton Road, which was a bit dodgy in 2004 Croft road,

Comfy chairs. Kate's cottage is isolated. Washing machine in kitchen.

From 2010 - two of the cottages are together and one is separated.
Names: The Nest, The Hobbit
The area behind the rare breeds in the lee of the copes is South facing and used for the vineyard,it is only a couple of acres.

Quite a large house. Slate roof, large garden with lawns and stables, good views. Dining room, sitting room, study with computer and fax, polished floors in the kitchen and the hall. Phone in the kitchen, new front door bell. Several bedrooms. Self contained flat  	

The view from the sitting room window is wonderful. They have their own stables.  The dining room is north west facing.

From the village go out on the Hollerton Road and it's the big house on the left, about half a mile down.
12 Old People's bungalows on the edge of the green: Old people’s bungalows opposite the village hall.  The warden lives at number 12, Mr. Pullen at number 7, Mrs. Potter at number 10.

From Sharon's bedroom window she can see the church clock.
2 bed
Market Day is Wednesday

The conservatory is triple glazed. The lawn slopes down to the river You can see the business unit's car park from the bathroom window. Six bedrooms. (as they now have a study it could be 5 bed) Hallway from the front door, large and dark & panelled. The backdoor leads into the kitchen and Lynda uses it when she has been in the garden - or is too wet/muddy to use the front door. You can also get into the house via the conservatory.  

Ambridge Hall, Penny Hassett Road, Ambridge.

In 1994 Lynda installed a Low Allergen garden with and water feature and small kitchen garden (possibly incorporated in the low allergen area).  In 2003 this was it was refurbish. To extend the life of the house into the garden - she installed solar power lights around the water feature, and included a Shakespearean theme, using flowers mentioned by

Pub- known as "The Crown" called "The Crown and Cushion". Farmer Bob Henries has cattle  2 miles from Ambridge. Village Hall which can be hired for functions. Church St. Saviours. Small private girls school for children up to 11 years.
12.7.94 the shop closed. There is a pub called The Oak Tree where they have a great DJ. Millgate Farm.   5 miles from Ambridge
In 2009 the house is divided into Willow Farm house and Willow Cottage so that Roy, Hayley and the children have a place of their own. Mike's half is called Willow Cottage.
Formerly Sixpenny Farm.  1961 - Barratt's Farm (dairy) and Allards Farm were amalgamated with Brookfield to make up Ambridge Dairy Farmers.
After Amos's death, Dan buys the farm. Len and Mary Thomas live in the farmhouse.
Sept/October 1964 - Old Thornton Farm on the Estate was taken over by Nigel and Joan Hood.

Thatched. Central heating (put in by Peggy). French windows. Attic. Garden. Thick walls. Great view of the Hasset Hill from the back bed- room. There are raspberry canes in the back garden. Front garden gate painted with black enamel. Hydrangea bush. the sitting room which is at the front of the house.
Porch and pokey hallway. Good locks
Land that was let in eary 1996 went for £120 an acre. Hollerton Junction is the local train station, it's a very pretty run from Birmingham. 6 miles from Ambridge

Outside the village on the Felphersham Rd. Bought by Marjorie in 1985 she had the the whole buliding restored and the outbulidings converted into kennels for her dogs. The house is set well back from the road with half a acre of land. Marjorie lives in a muddle.
Nightingale Farm
The house was once used as an Art and Craft centre with a self contained flat it was converted back into home - but still with separate flat in 1985.

 In 2003 the house was sold to a property developer who completely restored it - to a high standard - and the flat was reabsorbed into the house

6 bedrooms 2 bathrooms parlour kitchen scullery large cellars
Banky field is quite a distance from the farm house. 120acres rented from the estate. Joe's bedroom is at the front of the house.
From November 2000 the farm was sold to Oliver Stirling with 50 acres of land - the remaining land become part of the estate.
Small pig unit. Aga. Just over 90 acres 60 milkers Geoff Travis runs the farm single handed

Home to Susan and Neil Carter - The Green Council Housing: All 12 houses are basically the same living room, small kitchen, bathroom, 2 or 3 bedrooms. The living rooms are about 24 square feet with a chimney breast that gets in the way, and porch to the front door. They are all semi-detached.
Before they moved in in ‘84, Neil and Susan had the house redecorated because it was in a very bad state: Their bedroom has white walls with blue flowers and blue curtains with white flowers.  The kitchen is white and there is an oatmeal carpet in the living room. They have a new front door.
Sawyers Farm..Computer/Printer..Blinds at the window. Filing Cabinet. Main office where Shula and another sit, posher smaller one off 1997 small office called "Mr Ryder's office"

Nursing home between Ambridge and Penny Hassett only about 2 miles from Ambridge.  Looks very modern. Pru Forrest has a room which has a picture window from which she can just see the outline of Lakey Hill. She has two chairs for visitors and a wash basin. Bus shelter outside, with a seat
The doctor's surgery is in the converted outbuildings. Small reception area. not enough parking. Fax.
From the Berrow you can see the Lickeys and the Malverns on a good day you can see the Brecon Beacons. There are earthworks.
Brookfield pig unit. May '96 At any one time they can have about 600 pigs Harry Roberts is Pigman. 98 Harry has now left. The Sow stalls have been removed.
The fire smokes. The bathroom and loo are in an extension at the back There is a telephone. No central heating.

General store with Post office. The P.O section is separate from the rest of the counter. Birthday cards are kept on a stand Super market baskets. There is a public notice board. Burglar Alarm. Self-service. Closes at 7pm week days and early on a Sunday.

See Community Shop storyline
Has an Aga. It is practically unfurnished

Single storey. Concrete floors. Built in 1990 the sitting room is 18ft 3" long.They have smoke alarms. The decor is emulsioned wood chip no pictures. Views over the Am.

Built in 1990 
River views (very close). The building can only be reached  by going through Brookfield’s yard. Three bedrooms, bathroom.  The living room is 18 feet long. Narrow hall. Fitted carpets throughout.  eat in kitchen.  They have smoke alarms fitted.
Outside there is a small Horse Chestnut, donated by Tom  who gave them a second  tree on the birth of Pip. The garden is not well kept. Sheep have been put in the near field just after lambing.
230 acres
28.11.96: Re-decorated light and airy, walls off white (blue) with elegant stencilling. Wine Bar renamed the Cafe Bar opened on New Years Eve 1996
Brand new showers in the pavilion (20.7.94) There is a garage in which they keep bits and bobs including the sit on mower
Pub in Borchester: Knaves Bar: Elizabeth loves going there -many years ago

Converted village school. Virginia creeper grows up the side. The Hall is owned by a charitable trust with the Parish Council as trustees. Administration is carried out by a management committee of 12 - 16 representatives 50% of whom are from the local groups using the hall - mothers and toddlers, wi, over 60s etc.
They have a cricket team who come top of the league. Pub/restaurant The Plough and Harrow
They use yellow plastic bags. In Borchester. In 1991 there were six branches  of Underwoods around the county
There is planty of light from the big windows in the main dining room

A pub off the Hollerton Rd. Wide screen TV Pool tables Juke box Happy hours. Grange Farm is halfway between the two pubs.
2005 converted into beautiful modern apartments with original features, windows, staircase, cornices, dado rails, all lovingly refurbished.
In 2006 the Country Park was sold separately from the hotel.  It is now owned by Borchester Land
Pub.."The Fox"

1,020 acres owned by Guy Pemberton and managed by his son Simon, of which 260 acres is let (Bridge Farm 140, Grange Farm120) leaving 760 acres in hand. Of this 110 is woodland and 80 acres in permanent grass (let to Brian Aldridge) 570 acres farmed by P Archer & Son.
soils at Home farm and the Estate are quite heavy, with parts that are heavy clay.
The Vetinary Surgery where Robin Stokes works is in Borchester. Robin does a surgery there, the senior partner is called Alistair, there is also a John and and Sally.

In 1997 the Borchester By Pass was due to be widened. This ment cutting down some woodland.  The village was split some for and some against. Kate and her friends set up a protest camp in the wood land. They build tree houses and dug tunnels.

A pair of semi-detached  cottages built in 1960 by Charles Grenville. Opposite Ambridge Hall close to Home and Willow Farms. Were owned by the Estate and now by Jack Woolley. Tom and Pru were the first people to live in Keeper’s Cottage. 
Two Bedrooms (after her illness Pru was unable to manage the stairs). 
Both cottages have a small hall, living room (to one side of the hall), and kitchen at the end of the hall the staircase is visible from the from door. Both have neat, well kept gardens.
April Cottage is the mirror of  Keeper’s.
Tom and Pru / Len and Mary Thomas move into the new cottages on 12.5.1960.
April Cottage Penny Hassett Road, Ambridge
Population about 600 in 1996. In the river Am there are Brown Trout (replaced by Phil in 1989)  "higher up" 6 miles South from Borchester and 17 miles West of Felpersham.
1999 Jack has agreed a lease of 125 years charging a peppercorn rent.
170 acres Bert Gibbs is the owner.
One of those little places near the church.
Next to the Village Hall
Usha's Office in Felpersham.
Shula started work for them on 13.12.76 and left on 8.4.97. Estate and Land agents in Borchester. Graham Ryder works there.
The Estate office
August 1990 - This school is the amalgamted schools of Borchester Free and Worcester Rd.
There are Alder trees beside the river
Leader's is one of the most ancient woodlands in Borsetshire.
In the shared garden there is some topiary which looks a bit like a mongoose.
Burnt down in 1984

All bedrooms have en suite facilities. Indoor pool, fully equipped gym and leisure centre. All at a cut-throat rate. Their clients can go rom their conferance to the bar and then to their rooms with digital TVs and air conditioning.

Wayne and Jolene have been given a starter home on the estate.
They have central heating.

Sebastopol Road on the fifth floor, it’s noisy and dirty the flat is very small with only two bedrooms. The view is good but of the next block of flats and if you stand on the balcony and crane your head to the left you could just see Haydon Berrow. There's a chip shop at the end of the road and a Chinese
Joe calls it the Old Wheeler's Lock
There is a historic farm near Brampton Green
Railway line which runs from Hollerton Junction to Upper Croft.  The line is used for Steam Trains and other specials including a Santa Special
The pub is called The Parrot

Café in Borchester with a flat upstairs
Gone

The new housing estate built in 2003 by Borchester Land on what use to be Grange Farm land - 12 big houses and 6 starter homes opposite Ambridge Farm down by Grange Farm. You can see the church from some of the back gardens.
The café in Oriel Road, Borchester owned by Jack Woolley - Kenton Archer is the manager and Emma Carter his assistant.
The landlord keeps a very good cellar.  It's ggod for real Ale

Neil and Susan's self build home moved in in 2005 : 
Ambridge View; four-bedroom house an ensuite bathroom, downstairs loo with a separate cloakroom, a utility room off the kitchen,  patio doors from the dinning room out onto some decking. They have a lovely view of the village, you can see Lakey Hill from the master bedroom.
3 bedrooms
On Home Farm Land

In Mach 2006 the golf course was sold separately from the rest of the hotel.  It is now owned by Borchester Land:
So Borchester Land own The Country park and The Golf course.
Special Needs School in Penny Hassett.
Part of the estate
Mike's half of Willow Farm  two bedrooms  one reception a small hallway and a dining kitchen a downstairs toilet and a new bathroom upstairs.
Homeless persons hostel in Borchester - see Christmas stroylines

The new bungalow on the sight of the old police house. The police house was burnt down.
Architecturally it isn't a gem more utilitarian - perfectly inoffensive. 
Next door to the shop and a short stroll to The Bull.
The garden is less than a quarter of an acre. Three bedrooms
Village near Ambridge where Mike and Jazzer deliver milk.
Village near Ambridge where Mike and Jazzer deliver milk.

The Hillside houses are on the road out to Lower Loxley, on the other side of Lakey Hill.  They're right by the road with no front gardens to speak of. The view of Lakey Hill isn't bad but there are large trees that makes them feel dark and damp
New development opened in 2011

On Home Farm land - a strip of land near Milennium Wood. Run by Jim as clerk to the parish council Mike is the manager (paid).  Mike has to keep an eye on the site and meet and greet the bereaved. Jim is his boss. Eddie is the grave digger again paid.
Kate and Lucas - with Phoebe until September 2012

Location: Melville, Johannesburg - Kate and Lucas's home
Description: South Africa

The gamekeeper's cottage on Home Farm land.  Very isolated -  small lounge. The kitchen has spotlights and new doors on the cupboards 2004. hand carved sign that says ‘Casa Nueva’ George carved the sign and Christopher forged the chain. 2 bedrooms + small box room. Nice big back garden. Gate into front garden
Before it was "Casa Nueva" it was Sammy Whipple's Cottage
Pat and Tony's organic farm shop in Borchester
Small over crowed. 3 bed house

At Sawyer's Farm the buildings converted into business units in 1995. with parking and landscaping. There is a barrier at the entrance. the old Dutch Barn was taken down. Alistair the vet had 2 knocked together.

In Felpersham
Daniel, Freddie and Lily attend
FE  and Sixth Form College

Ambridge church.1976 bells re hung for New year. There is a rail in front of the altar. Number 3 bell is fairly light. Church Brasses Cupboard in vestry. There is a public toilet. There are Yew Trees in the church yard.

The lectern and the Bishop’s chair in the church were made in 2004; they are of a modern design.

Flag pole on the tower
A huge agro-industrial complex. New buildings on the estate. The workers are housed at Vally Farm this is the site of the mega diary and AD unit
About 8 miles north of Borchester "as the crow flies"
pool, sauna, steam room, jacuzzi and treatments

24 bedrooms in house and 36 in annexe total of 60. The staff shifts are kept on a schedule. Take on extra staff in the summer months.Fax. There's a conference room called the Arkwright Room. You can bring your dog with you when you stay. Four star in January 1993
